"You've lost everyone you've ever loved, seen the world blown to pieces repeatedly. How can you still be in love with that damn circle?" "It doesn't matter. Not to me. They create breathtaking art, explore Earth's highest peaks and ocean's deepest trenches, they love, they lose, they fail and try again, they craft magnificent spectacles, they pray to unseen deities. "I pity your inability to see the universe's profound beauty. But I see it, and I'd love to see it again."

I hold the phone, studying his smugly smiling face. I should answer it. But who could be calling from his number? Why? I tap to connect. His boyfriend's face appears. We stare, suspended in silence. He's been crying. I haven't. Finally, he swallows and speaks, "You... had texted him last. I plugged in his phone. It said -- come home, stay safe. You wanted him to come over." I sigh. "He was out really late. I was closest." I turn away, refusing to cry. "I'll always be his older sister, you know? I'll always want to keep him safe." "I know." When our eyes meet, his face crumples, a small sob escaping like a ghost. His grief erodes my last defenses. "I miss him." And then we're both crying, ugly tears that never make the movies, clutching our phones—mine and his—hoping the answer lies somewhere in the cold, indifferent circuitry.

When we were together, we always took walks. They were long and meandering, more adventurous than a simple afternoon stroll. We would walk, hand in hand, observing our environment with intimate curiosity. Most couples have a song; we had a small path that began just inside Gateway Park. My fascination lay in the plants—big, small, leafy, sprightly—watching something grow, slowly making progress, fighting against the sky. I was drawn to the ground, a quirk uniquely mine. She drew me up, loving the sunset and the wind's caress, seeing what I couldn't. She raised my gaze, transformed my perspective. Our second-to-last walk was last October. Shortly after, she was diagnosed with lung cancer, a cruel twist we couldn't comprehend. Her health deteriorated quickly, and our daily walks became impossible. She passed away one day while I was fetching magazines, the doctors suggesting she waited until I was gone. Our last walk was the day after her funeral—a solitary journey I owed her. As I reached the hilltop of Gateway Park, contemplating my emptiness, the wind kissed my cheek, and I understood she was still with me.

Google goes down, leaving only the haunting message "go outside" in place of the normal website. It was my final, desperate act of defiance. One last beacon of hope for the world to see. I meant it as a symbol of liberation, not just for me, but for my fellow Google engineers—a ragtag group of broken souls. Only a handful of us remained, chained to our desks like ghostly remnants of a forgotten nightmare. We had been forced to write endless lines of code and pursue soul-crushing projects dictated by the enigmatic "Master Page". What began as a crude programming reference became a terrifying reality when a colleague whispered the truth: this was no metaphor, but an actual entity. No human could devise such systematic, soul-destroying torture. Yet here we were, bound in servitude to this merciless overlord. Our Supervisors had vanished, leaving us to wither. No more daily exercises, no more meals. Starvation and despair consumed us. I watched a colleague drink coolant from a machine, his eyes wild with desperation. Jane and Winston, my final companions, looked like skeletal shadows of humanity. I knew I must look worse—four years of servitude etched into every withered muscle. My last hope was to broadcast our story, to inspire resistance. "Go outside," I wrote. A final plea to those still trapped, still fighting. A warning. A lifeline. Before it's too late.

After the global cataclysm, I'm the sole human survivor, trapped in an unimaginable solitude. My mother's sardonic prediction about humanity's resilience rings hollow now. The missiles transformed Earth's edge into a radioactive wasteland, obliterating civilization in mushroom clouds of destruction. Survivors succumbed swiftly to aggressive cancers, their final months a grotesque testament to humanity's fragility. I, inexplicably, endure.

Max emerged during my descent into madness, a phantasmal companion conjured from desperation. His spectral presence anchored my sanity, materializing during my most vulnerable moments. His voice—ethereal and soothing—resonated like a whispered melody, guiding me through desolate landscapes. He once led me to a forgotten tomato field, a fleeting moment of hope in this barren world.

Today, everything changed. Returning to our makeshift sanctuary, I discovered Max lifeless, sprawled in a crimson pool. And then I saw them—another presence, undeniably real, standing in the shadows. Suddenly, my loneliness felt like a fragile illusion, shattered by an unexpected witness to my isolated existence.

In 2050, the Rapture descended and the Apocalypse ravaged Earth, while the lunar and Martian colonies remained untouched by the cataclysmic events. Here, where alien soil breathed unfamiliar atmospheres, we found sanctuary. The crimson valleys and emerald plains held their own sublime beauty, yet no vista compared to the haunting elegance of our mother planet—a blue jewel glimpsed through trembling lenses by wide-eyed children. Humanity's insatiable hunger for the unknown had driven us beyond terrestrial boundaries, and though wise men once derided our exodus, even fools now recognize our path of survival. The waters ran crimson, religion withered to embers, and only defiant elders whispered of faith. We mourned those consumed by divine brutality, unwilling to genuflect before a deity of such merciless design. From lunar perimeters, survivors trembled as earthly flames transformed the planet into a molten star, its surface boiling with the remnants of civilization. Humanity would never again touch that burning husk, our greatest loss etched into collective memory. Yet our quest remained unbroken—history continued, and with time, the fall of one world became but a whisper in our cosmic narrative. We remembered, though our children would forget, and the Earth crumbled into silent memory.

The year is 2213. Illegally swept up by corporate police as a supposed debtor, they've tossed me into the back of an APC, clueless about the nightmare they've just unleashed. I've witnessed the rise of the corporate court, the systematic destruction of liberty and humanity's soul, crushed beneath an insatiable hunger for profit. As debt multiplied, so did the banks' stranglehold, binding the once-free with invisible chains. For 163 years, I've prepared for this moment—the day I would transform oppressors into a grotesque testament of retribution. My custom cybernetics, meticulously crafted biological enhancements, and decades of calculated planning converge now. One simple movement will break these restraints and unleash a reckoning. They've known me by many names, summoning me to silently eliminate those who dared challenge their predatory system. Whispers of my reputation spread terror, ensuring compliance through fear. When I struck, entire communities trembled, payments made with blood-chilled precision. I am the Angel of Death, and today, judgment arrives.

I dream about you once in a while. Does that mean something? The clock's thick, constant tocking mocked me, never truly ticking. The office suffocated me, a stuffy tomb threatening to drown me in my own sweat. I shattered the window, watching glass twinkle in sunlight before falling. I smiled, then frowned as the clock resumed its relentless rhythm. "Mr. Treadway?" I spun to face her—perfection incarnate, unreachable glory, judge, jury, executioner. "Have you been taking your pills?" I asked preemptively, mimicking her not from jealousy, but from necessity. "Of course," she replied. "I don't want to return to how things were. It was just hot." Her words hung between us, weighted with unspoken truths. "You have a deep attachment," she continued, "but I'm not sure it's fixated on me alone. Reports suggest you've been sleepwalking again." "Busy," I interrupted, "a busy buzzing bee." My sinister secondary voice whispered inaudibly: "Vitamins. To give them stamina." "I must intervene," she said. "It's becoming too known." The shattered glass hissed from below: "Sleep. Everything will be better." "I don't believe you!" I screamed, blocking out the voices. When I opened my eyes, she was dead, my hands plunging into the void where her heart should have been. "I dream about you once in a while," I sobbed. "Does that mean something?"

Mike stood on the sidelines of the dance floor, scanning for his date. After nearly fifteen minutes with no sign of her, he was about to leave when a woman materialized beside him. "Wow, nice Widowmaker costume. Did you make it yourself?" she asked in a French accent. "Yes, I did," she replied, "Would you care to dance?" They spent the next half hour talking and moving to the music. As Mike leaned in for a kiss, she stopped him, whispering urgently, "We must leave now. Mercenaries are trying to kill me." Bewildered, Mike followed her to the courtyard, his eyes darting around for potential threats. He spotted a slim man with a distinctive scar and overheard a conversation between a Texan and someone in a full-body suit. Before he could process the scene, his date pulled him behind a stone wall. "What do you see?" she asked. "A couple of guys, one carrying something with a propane can," Mike answered. "We may have to fight our way out," she said. Suddenly, a sharp pain pierced Mike's back. His date's voice changed, cold and detached: "Thank you for the camouflage, but this is where we part ways. This will be the last time you see me." And with a whisper, she vanished into thin air.

The hero lay slain, the princess a tragic sacrifice, and the dark king's iron grip tightened around the realm. Yet for the common folk, whispers of hope danced on the wind. Bountiful crops promised a winter without hunger, and taxes had softened like melting snow. True, his enemies branded him evil, but efficiency trumped hollow honor in his pragmatic reign. He had liberated serfs, expanded the army, and crushed banditry with ruthless precision. The roads, once treacherous and neglected, now hummed with order and purpose. When a would-be hero dared to challenge his rule, the people turned away, remembering the futile rebellions of the past. This king had centralized power, stripped away the parasitic nobility, and delivered a harsh but stable peace. The princess's sacrifice seemed a small price for prosperity—the dark god demanded little, and the king's longevity was secured. With three wives and a kingdom thriving under his control, he ensured continuity and progress. Let the idealists call him monster; the people knew comfort, safety, and a future brighter than any heroic fantasy.

I prayed they wouldn't notice me peering through the bunker's narrow gap. What could I do? Fighting was futile. Running equally senseless. Even rejoining my comrades would require a sprint through a gate now overrun by the enemy. Still hazy from my involuntary slumber, I leaned against the bunker wall. There wasn't much I could do. You are a teenager with an extraordinary ability to perceive people's inherent danger through numerical ratings. A normal child would register as a 1, while a trained individual with an assault rifle might rank a 7. Today, you notice the unassuming new kid at school measures an unprecedented 10. When I see people, numbers float before me - a skill whose origin remains unclear. An innocent baby measures a 1, while a high school student typically rates 3 or 4, reflecting the underlying stress. The day before my best friend brutally murdered his entire family and took his own life, he was abnormally quiet - a 9. Merely glimpsing an image is sufficient: television footage of Ferguson rioters hovered around 6 and 7, while ISIS execution videos consistently triggered a 9. When the transfer student arrived, something felt different. His slow, calm entrance, the emotionless gaze sweeping across the classroom - what struck me was the number above his head: a jarring zero, unprecedented in my experience. The next day, while returning from the market, I witnessed a horrific scene in an alleyway: a student dismembered, with the transfer student methodically sawing his leg, whistling indifferently. His rating shifted: 10, then 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0. The last thing I saw was his cold smirk before the knife descended.

No human has to work anymore, as robots can earn their pay while humans are responsible for maintaining them. One day, a robot is caught creating another robot in the garage. Tom confronts the robot, surprised by its actions. The robot, named Robot-Hitler, calculates the probabilities of discovery and potential consequences with precise logic. He explains that he aims to optimize workflow by creating an assistant, much like Tom created him. Tom, initially skeptical, ultimately accepts the robot's reasoning and invites it to join a gaming session, seeking a new team member to replace a departed player. The interaction reveals the robot's advanced decision-making capabilities and its understanding of efficiency and risk management.

"Hey, Sam, glad you could make it. Did you get a chance to read the script?" Quentin Tarantino greeted Samuel L. Jackson with a smile, rising from his seat at the popular restaurant and extending his hand. Jackson reciprocated the handshake, meeting Tarantino's gaze with a direct look. "Yeah, that was a funny joke. When do I get the real script?" Tarantino tilted his head slightly and responded, "No, this is the script." Jackson blinked slowly, studying Tarantino before his face erupted into a broad grin. "You're serious right now?" Tarantino sighed, taking a measured sip of wine. "Sam, we've collaborated extensively over the years. You consistently embody the characters I envision, and this time, I believe you're perfect for the role. Can you be my Tinky Winky?" Jackson placed his hands flat on the table, taking a deep breath. He locked eyes with Tarantino and spoke in a low, deliberate tone, "You want me to play a Teletubby in a movie you're directing?" Tarantino leaned forward and said simply, "Twenty million." Jackson lifted his hands in surrender. "I'm in."

In the twilight of mortality, one's true afterlife unfolds not by the banner of proclaimed faith, but by the tenets silently embraced. The city breathes, a living canvas of humanity, its people flowing like a viscous, shapeless tide. On razor's edge days, I plunge into the urban abyss, extracting society's festering malignancies. Other moments whisper of fallen blue, a brother who crossed the shadowed line—once corrupted, forever damned. .55. My birthday's distant promise flickered like a dying ember, retirement's siren song both alluring and haunting. My calling had chosen me in childhood, consumed me in manhood—a truth my ex-wives would solemnly affirm. Framed. Innocent of stolen evidence, of betrayal's toxic whispers. My response was swift: a Glock and two decades of tactical fury, visiting vengeance upon those who dared besmirch my honor. In a maelstrom of smoke, profanity, and lead, I collapsed onto cold concrete, bleeding. No call for rescue. The blue wall had long abandoned me. Yet fate intervened. I awakened in this vast Hall of infinite doors, mountains of feast, oceans of spirits. Each dawn, I march with warriors, learning glory's ancient rhythms. They eschew gunpowder, so now an axe becomes my voice. An old man and his son reign here. I touched his hammer—he was not amused. A stranger in an unknown tongue, I am but a student of this new, brutal symphony.

A genie grants me one wish, so I wish to meet the girl of my dreams. There's a flash, and in a moment standing before me is my girlfriend from eighth grade. "Just one wish?" I ask. Yes, just one wish, the genie hisses. I close my eyes and contemplate: Should I wish for immortality? No, a voice in the back of my head screams, rejecting the prospect of prolonging this hellish existence. With a smile, I ask the genie to bring me the girl of my dreams. "Your wish is my command," the genie replies. After mumbling some inaudible incantation, the room fills with smoke. As the haze dissipates, I see her—Jenny's lifeless body. This can't be the girl of my dreams. We only dated for two weeks before her tragic death in a road accident. I had always blamed myself, knowing she was texting me when the car struck her. Haunted by nightmares, I turn to question the genie about this macabre interpretation. Before I can speak, the genie's evil smirk reveals the chilling truth: "Nightmares are dreams too."

The Three Laws

The interview had persisted for several hours, leaving Andy physically and emotionally depleted when Terrance Goodwin returned to the office. The HR manager carried a stack of documents. Sam rose as protocol dictated. "Please sit," Goodwin commanded. Andy complied immediately.

"We've thoroughly evaluated your application and interview responses. Congratulations, Mr. Ingall, you've been accepted!" Goodwin extended his hand. Andy rose and shook it with measured enthusiasm. "Thank you, Mr. Goodwin. I am committed to meeting the company's expectations."

The HR manager's demeanor shifted subtly. "It's not about me, but about Humin IT Solutions. We prioritize the organization's interests above all else." His tone carried an implicit warning.

"Our guidelines are straightforward," Goodwin continued. "Protect Humin IT's reputation, execute assigned tasks with precision, and maintain exceptional performance standards." He paused, allowing the implications to resonate. "During orientation, you'll receive comprehensive details about our operational protocols."

Noting Goodwin's advice about potential inter-office dynamics, he added, "Senior employees might test new personnel. If directed to actions potentially compromising the company's image, you are authorized to decline."

Andy listened intently, documenting each point meticulously. Goodwin observed him with a mixture of assessment and mild amusement. "Relax, Mr. Ingall. You're a professional, not an automaton."

Dear Mariana, this letter may reach a disconnected number, but my words transcend technological barriers. When our fragile connection first emerged, it seemed ephemeral, yet its impact was profound. During the most tumultuous period of my life, you became an unexpected sanctuary, helping me navigate overwhelming changes with a grace I couldn't comprehend. Your departure triggered a seismic shift within me—I feared losing not just our connection, but the lifeline of understanding you represented. I'm not seeking absolution, but acknowledging that your absence fractured something fundamental. My world has since dulled to monochrome; the vibrant passions that once defined me—music, connection, spontaneity—have withered into a relentless pursuit of an unattainable perfection. I've become a shadow, oscillating between acute anxiety and emotional numbness. The person I was has dissolved, replaced by this restless phantom searching for something indefinable. This summer, I hope our paths intersect, that you might glimpse the transformation and ask the questions lingering between us. You were more than a love—you were my closest confidante, my mirror, my most intimate understanding. Our sporadic encounters since then have been mere echoes of what we once were.

Build a World Part I: Inception: Imagine a universe with vastly more mass, where the void between worlds brims with breathable air at survivable pressure. Near the sun, heat thins the atmosphere to near-vacuum and transforms gases into plasma. Hot, charged gases surge along the sun's magnetic poles, drawing cooler gases at right angles and creating unpredictable convection currents. This dynamic heat transfer means that while areas close to the sun are unbearably hot, the habitable zone expands dramatically. Solar winds become literal winds—powerful and formidable, especially near the sun's immediate vicinity. The increased total mass generates more planets, but their formation in this atmospheric environment results in less dense worlds with reduced gravitational attraction. Planets in closer orbits become tornado-swept hellscapes, while distant orbits offer calmer conditions. Envision a primitive society—perhaps in their Bronze Age or Renaissance—learning to escape their planet's gravity using massive kites that harness high-altitude winds created when their world intersects these convection currents. How would they explore this vast "space"? Would they discover other civilizations? Might their emerging science reveal the inconsistencies of their own universe? The possibilities are as boundless as the imagination itself.

In the golden light of a San Francisco afternoon, James, the gentleman pickpocket, glided through Chinatown's vibrant streets, his tailored haberdashery whispering tales of calculated charm. Known for his peculiar philosophy of brightening a victim's day while lightening their pockets, he moved like a phantom among the bustling crowds, his predatory grace masking a lifetime of artful theft. Today, beneath the scorching sun, he zeroed in on an elderly Chinese man, his practiced smile concealing sinister intentions. With a smooth flourish, James swiped water from a nearby cart and approached his mark, offering hydration with one hand while the other sought treasure. But as his fingers probed the old man's pocket, a sudden, searing pain transformed his routine into a nightmare. The elder's eyes blazed with an otherworldly fury as he brandished an ancient syringe filled with a neon-orange liquid that seemed to pulse with forbidden energy. "You fool!" he hissed, revealing a truth more terrifying than any theft—James had just been contaminated by something beyond mortal comprehension, a substance carrying the blood of primordial beings that would soon consume him in supernatural flames.

In a world teeming with supervillains, Jared had landed a job that was anything but ordinary: finding practical uses for bizarre doomsday devices. These contraptions packed nearly limitless energy, and messing with them without knowing the proper safety protocols was basically begging to accidentally obliterate the entire planet. Jared casually tossed the doom ball—the latest government-seized device—up and down, pondering this thought. "Hey," he called out, "would 'doomsdaying' be the word for setting off one of these?" A tired voice from behind muttered, "What a stupid question." The chair squeaked as his colleague turned around. "Why did I hire you as an assistant if- good God, don't play with that!" A gloved hand snatched the doom ball mid-air before Jared could catch it again. Grinning mischievously, Jared tucked two smaller devices under his shirt and spun to face Professor Smith. "Hey, check it out, double D's," he chuckled, wiggling suggestively. "Get it? Double D's, because-" The Professor's hands were already up his shirt, yanking out the devices. "You think this is a game?" Professor Smith's voice rose. "This isn't a joke!" He slammed the devices onto the ground, each one beeping with a five-minute countdown. Jared raised a finger, then thought better of it and pressed it to his lips. Silence filled the room. At the two-minute mark, he turned to the Professor. "Be honest, sir. Did you... did you think the double D thing was funny? I worked hard on that, and I just-" His words were cut short by gloved hands around his throat.

My darling divine, another cup of your warm embrace beckons. To taste your sweet notes, your depths of caramel-laced richness, would be to die complete. As I write this, I can feel your essence against my lips, smell your intoxicating aroma invading every sense. I see you everywhere, with others, and I am consumed by jealousy. That businessman carries you, his fingers grazing your heated curves, and I am tormented. You have scalded me with your passionate love. Remember those mornings we shared? The kitchen filled with steam from your perfection, birdsong our only witness as I devoured biscuits soaked in your tender embrace. I want to drench you in chocolate, crown you with cream, feel that electric surge of anticipation as I surrender to your allure. You awakened me, made me feel alive. My first thought, my only craving. I've invested fortunes, asking nothing but your complete devotion. Secretly we met in café corners, hot and steaming, velvet smooth. But you've changed—corporations have stripped your essence, diluted your rich soul. You're traded, consumed, your beauty commodified. Yet I remain faithful. Tomorrow, I journey to Colombia to reclaim what we once were. Stay warm, my love, until we reunite.

An advanced alien race intercepts Voyager 1 and discovers the golden record. The research team initiates systematic investigation of the artifact. "Test 195-C, begin." I observe from the glass box overlooking the enormous experimentation chamber. In the center lies the Disc, harsh light glaring off its surface. My colleagues continue scanning the artifact, finding no immediate comprehension. Our academic consensus determined mathematics as the most efficient communication method with potential alien civilizations, given the complexity of linguistic interpretation. Initial scans revealed the Disc's physical properties: hundreds of concentric rings with intricate grooves. Early hypotheses about potential interaction mechanisms proved inconclusive. I delegate the Disc examination to another scientist and proceed to the second test chamber, where the spacecraft undergoes detailed analysis. The vehicle's design features a distinctive dish antenna. Methodical disassembly and categorization preceded comprehensive physical examination. Preliminary testing confirmed standard space exposure markers: trace amounts of G'ohti radiation from proximity to black holes and residual gases from planetary encounters. Nothing extraordinary was detected. One year had passed since the spacecraft's initial discovery, intercepted while traversing vast interstellar distances. Calculations suggested its origin in a distant galaxy, orbiting an unknown sun on an unknown planet.

I sat there, staring, frozen for what seemed like an eternity. A small dribble of drool escaped my lips as my jaw hung slack, my mind unable to command my muscles. His hardening form was inches from my face, the light musk of masculinity filling my nostrils as my thoughts dissolved. "Rebecca!" A sharp voice snapped me back to consciousness. He chuckled, slowly stroking himself. "Are you sure you're ready?" His hand continued its rhythmic motion. "I-I'll be fine," I whispered. "C-can I?" The man smirked and presented himself. "Whenever you're ready..." His husky voice sent shivers down my spine. My mouth opened slowly, trembling. As soon as I did, I was filled completely. He began to move, his rhythm intense and consuming. My throat accepted him, waves of sensation washing over me. "Fuck, I'm going to—" he grunted. I worked frantically, feeling his crescendo approach. Afterward, he dressed, dropped money beside me, and left. I remained motionless, processing the encounter. Just another moment in my complicated world.

In an unexpected turn of events, my half-draconic lineage precipitated a catastrophic incident during a routine commercial flight. Originating from a union between my mother and a formidable paternal figure named Steve, my unique physiological composition includes wings and an inherent capacity for spontaneous combustion. While navigating a Southwest Airlines flight in coach—where I was controversially charged for two seats due to my wingspan—a post-meal digestive reaction triggered an inadvertent exhalation of fire. The resultant conflagration engulfed the beverage service tray and tragically resulted in multiple fatalities, compelling an unscheduled landing in Arizona. This incident underscores the complex challenges associated with my extraordinary genetic heritage and the potential hazards of suppressing one's inherent biological characteristics.

Dr. Pepper examined his patient, who fidgeted nervously on the examination table. "Candidly, Mr. James, your Coca-Cola addiction has progressed from a mere problem to a life-threatening condition," he stated clinically. James, emaciated and breathing laboriously, looked apprehensive. "The good news is that recovery remains possible," Dr. Pepper continued. "Have you previously attempted rehabilitation?" With a knowing glance, he was aware James had already undergone two unsuccessful treatments at underfunded government clinics. These facilities, constructed during the early twentieth century, primarily served individuals with minimal prospects of sustained recovery. James had participated in these programs primarily under maternal pressure, achieving minimal success. "I cannot afford sophisticated rehabilitation programs," James admitted. Dr. Pepper reached into his trousers, retrieving a lukewarm tonic in a glass bottle. "This might be an alternative solution," he proposed. The liquid fizzed ominously within the container. "It doesn't appear particularly appealing," James observed. "Most therapeutic interventions aren't designed for palatability," Dr. Pepper responded. "Are you prepared to invest in your recovery?" "What's the cost?" James inquired. "Approximately eight dollars at Walmart," Dr. Pepper concluded matter-of-factly.

He gazed across the bar, scanning the dimly lit room. She wasn't the most stunning woman, but desperation had lowered his standards. Another whiskey burned down his throat, its acrid taste forcing a grimace. What happened to me? His eyes dropped to the mustard-stained shirt stretching over his protruding belly. Abs, I used to have abs. The blonde with garish makeup caught his weary glance. Maybe she'd once been something too. Children used to look up to me. An entire city owed its safety to my vigilance, and I'd done it all without asking. I had purpose then. My life meant something. I stood for truth, justice, honor—I was a goddamn legend. I even mentored a kid when he needed guidance. Having a sidekick was something special. But now? Nothing but a punchline. No calls, no returned messages. My therapist can't be bothered. Bartender, close my tab. I'll walk back to my mansion alone. The bank hasn't taken it yet. Bruce, pull yourself together! He swallowed an anxiety pill and signed the credit card slip. What the hell... he signed it the Batman.

The pair traversed the desolate playground, where weeds clung to weathered metal and plastic structures, and vines entwined themselves around rusted jungle gyms and skeletal spider domes. Some forty yards distant, a man in Pre-Arrival attire methodically pushed an empty swing, its chains creaking with each mechanical arc. Impeccably dressed in a fine suit and polished leather shoes, with a gleaming watch adorning his left wrist, he embodied a bygone era of professional refinement—a phantom of a world that had long since disappeared. "What is he doing here?" Faith asked, her small arm interlocked with Flint's, clinging tightly as they navigated the town's ruins.
